definition: to cause an accident/to make trouble/to get into trouble
to rush/to charge/to dash/to break through/to temper oneself (through battling hardships)

sentences.english: We have got into trouble here, I say we bail.
sentences.chinese: 我們闖禍了，我說咱們開溜吧。

sentences.english: The drivers who habitually cut in will cause an accident sooner or later.
sentences.chinese: 那些總愛搶道的司機總有一天會闖禍。

sentences.english: If you get into trouble again, you'll be expelled .
sentences.chinese: 如果你再闖禍就會被開除的。

sentences.english: I'll be as prim as I can and not get into any scrapes , if I can help it.
sentences.chinese: 我會盡量板着面孔，不去闖禍，如果我能做到的話。

sentences.english: Mufasa:Being brave doesn't mean you go looking for trouble.
sentences.chinese: 《獅子王》“勇敢並不代表你要四處闖禍。”

sentences.english: In 1, he kept making mistakes, angered the father scolded him look fierce and talk boisterously.
sentences.chinese: 他不停闖禍犯錯，惹得父親疾言厲色地責罵他。

sentences.english: He is an impudent boy and always gets in trouble.
sentences.chinese: 他是個魯莽的男孩，經常會闖禍。

sentences.english: We knew that a kid who collected junk had little time to get into trouble.
sentences.chinese: 我們知道，拾垃圾的小人沒有多少時間闖禍。

sentences.english: The heedless boy was always getting into trouble.
sentences.chinese: 這個粗心大意的男孩總是闖禍。

sentences.english: This had happened many times since he left school.
sentences.chinese: 自從他離開學校後他經常闖禍。

definition: to amuse oneself/to play with/to tease
vocal accompaniment in some traditional Chinese operas/to speak in support of/to chime in
to throw one's life in for/to haplessly give one's life for/to sacrifice oneself torturously working for another or for a group/to pour in one's utmost effort/to shed one's last ounce of strength for
to have a clear view of things/to adapt to circumstances
(of a plot etc) to fall through and stand exposed
lit. the soul of a deceased has not yet dispersed (idiom)/fig. the influence still lingers on/the spirit (of some doctrine) is still alive
lit. helping tyrant Zhou 商紂王|商纣王[Shang1 Zhou4 wang2] in his oppression (idiom)/fig. to take the side of the evildoer/giving succor to the enemy
to stir up trouble/to invite disaster
to sound out the difficulties and retreat to avoid defeat (idiom); fig. to back out of an awkward situation/to get out on finding out what it's really like
to rack one's brains (idiom); to take great pains to think sth through
